sen.j: 土井 虎賀壽（どい とらかず、1902年2月19日 - 1971年3月10日）は、思想家・文学者。
sen.e: Torakazu DOI (February 19, 1902 - March 10, 1971) was a thinker and a scholar of literature.
Torakazu DOI (February 19, 1902 - March 10, 1971) was a thinker and literary scholar.
Torakazu DOI (February 19, 1902 - March 10, 1971) was a philosopher and literatus.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 香川県出身。
sen.e: He was from Kagawa Prefecture.
He was from Kagawa Prefecture.
He was from Kagawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 香川県木田郡の医師の家に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born into a doctor's family in Kita District, Kagawa Prefecture.
He was born into a doctor's family in the Kita district of Kagawa Prefecture.
He was born into a doctor's family in the Kita-gun (Kita County) of Kagawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 旧姓久保。
sen.e: His former family name was Kubo.
His former family name was Kubo.
His original family name was Kubo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 第三高等学校 (旧制)理科乙類（医学）から京都帝国大学理学部（物理）へ進むが、哲学科へ再入学、1926年卒業。
sen.e: Although he entered the Faculty of Science (school of physics) in Kyoto Imperial University, from the former Third High School (Daisan Koto Gakko, referred to as "Sanko"), Science Otsurui (second class)(school of medicine), he reenrolled in the Faculty of Philosophy and graduated in 1926.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although he entered the Department of Science (school of physics) at Kyoto Imperial University, from the former Third High School (Daisan Koto Gakko, referred to as "Sanko"), Science Otsurui (second class) (school of medicine), he re-enrolled in the Department of Philosophy and graduated in 1926.

He studied in the second group of the Science Department (in medicine) at the Daisan Koto Gakko (the "Third Senior High School" under the old system, often abbreviated to "Sanko") before moving on to the Department of Science (in Physics) at Kyoto Imperial University, but then re-enrolled in the Department of Philosophy, graduating in 1926.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: いったん実家に帰り女学校に勤め結婚する。
sen.e: He returned to his parents' home to work for a girls' school, then he married.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He returned to his parents' home in order to work for a girls' school, and then he married.
After graduating he temporarily moved back in to his parents' home, whereupon he took up a teaching job at a local girls' school and also married.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、二年で妻に先立たれ京都へ戻って大学院に進む。
sen.e: However, he had his wife die ahead of him in two years and thus returned to Kyoto to enter the graduate school.
However, his wife died just two years later, so he returned to Kyoto in order to enter the graduate school.
But his wife died after just two years, so he returned to Kyoto, entering graduate school there.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1929年、三高講師となる。
sen.e: He became an instructor at Sanko in 1929.
He became an instructor at Sanko in 1929.
In 1929 he became an instructor at the Third High School.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1941年、三高教授、京都帝大講師となる。
sen.e: In 1941, he became a professor at Sanko and an instructor at the Kyoto Imperial University.
In 1941, he became a professor at Sanko and an instructor at Kyoto Imperial University.
Then in 1941, be became both a Third High School Professor and an instructor at Kyoto Imperial University.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1948年、三高、京大を辞職、東京大学仏文科大学院に入学して二年間学ぶ。
sen.e: In 1948, he resigned from Sanko and the Kyoto Imperial University and entered the graduate school of University of Tokyo, Department of French literature and learned for two years.
In 1948, he resigned from Sanko and Kyoto Imperial University and entered graduate school at the University of Tokyo, Department of French Literature, and studied there for two years.
In 1948 he resigned from the Third High School and from Kyoto Imperial University and entered Tokyo University's graduate school in the Department of French Literature, studying there for two years.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1953年、相模女子大学教授、学習院大学講師となる。
sen.e: In 1953, he became a professor at Sagami Women's University and an instructor at Gakushuin University.
In 1953, he became a professor at Sagami Women's University and an instructor at Gakushuin University.
In 1953, he became a professor at Sagami Women's University and an instructor at Gakushuin University.

sen.j: 1964年、獨協大学初代学長天野貞祐の招きを受け外国語学部教授となり、「哲学」・「外国文学」を担当する。
sen.e: In 1964, he accepted the invitation from the first president Teiyu AMANO of Dokkyo University and became a professor of foreign languages and taught "philosophy" and "foreign literature."
In 1964, he accepted an invitation from Teiyu AMANO, the first president of Dokkyo University, and became a professor of foreign languages, whereupon he taught philosophy and "foreign literature."

Teiyu AMANO, the first president of Dokkyo University, had invited him to take up a position there, and in 1964 he accepted, entering the Department of Foreign Languages as the professor in charge of Philosophy and Foreign Literature.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 「土井虎（ドイトラ）」の愛称で親しまれ、京都学派の「異端児」・「奇人哲学者」として知られた。
sen.e: He was fondly called "Doitora" and known as an "enfant terrible" and an "eccentric philosopher" of the Kyoto school.
He was fondly called "Doitora" at the Kyoto school, and was known as an "enfant terrible" and an "eccentric philosopher."
Nicknamed "Doitora" by his students, the popular Doi was known as a "maverick" and "eccentric thinker" of the Kyoto School (of philosophical thought).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 京都では西田幾多郎、田辺元、天野貞祐らに学ぶ。
sen.e: In Kyoto, he learned from Kitaro NISHIDA, Hajime TANABE, and Teiyu AMANO.
In Kyoto, he studied under Kitaro NISHIDA, Hajime TANABE and Teiyu AMANO.
While in Kyoto, he had studied under Kitaro NISHIDA, Hajime TANABE, and Teiyu AMANO.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 戦後、哲学から文学への転向を目指し、辰野隆に師事すべく職を捨てて東大大学院に入るが辰野はその年退官であった。
sen.e: After the war, he gave up his job to be diverted away from philosophy toward literature, and entered the graduate school of the University of Tokyo to study under Yutaka TATSUNO; however, Tatsuno retired from the University the same year.

After the war, he gave up his job and turned from philosophy toward literature, whereupon he entered the graduate school of the University of Tokyo to study under Yutaka TATSUNO; however, Tatsuno retired from the university that same year.

After the war, aiming to shift from philosophy to literature, he quit his job and entered the graduate school of the University of Tokyo in order to study under Yutaka TATSUNO, but Tatsuno retired that very year.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、この行動がマスコミに賞賛されたことから土井ブームが起こった。
sen.e: This behavior, however, received acclaim from the mass media, thus creating a Doi boom.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This behavior, however, received acclaim from the mass media, thus creating a Doi boom.
In any event, his unconventional career decisions earned him acclaim in the mass media and led to something of a "Mr. Doi boom."
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 続けざまに『世界文学』などへの投稿や著書、またフリードリヒ・ニーチェの翻訳を刊行する。
sen.e: He wrote for magazines such as "Sekai Bungaku" (world literature) one after another, and published his writings and translations of Friedrich Nietzsche's books.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He wrote articles magazines such as "Sekai Bungaku (World Literature)" one after another, and published his writings and translations of Friedrich Nietzsche's books.
He published a steady stream of articles in "Sekai Bungaku" (World Literature) and other journals, and also published his translations of Friedrich NIETZSCHE's books.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1954年当時東大寺官長の上司海雲から「華厳経」のドイツ語訳を委嘱され、十年の歳月を費やしこの難事業を完成する。
sen.e: In 1954, Kaiun KAMITSUKASA, the then chief servant of Todai-ji Temple, commissioned Torakazu to translate "Kegon-kyo Sutra" into German and finally completed the painstaking work after ten years.
In 1954, Kaiun KAMITSUKASA, who was then the chief servant of Todai-ji Temple, commissioned Torakazu to translate "Kegon-kyo Sutra" into German; the painstaking work was completed after ten years.

In 1954, Kaiun KAMITSUKASA, who at that time was the chief official of Todai-ji Temple, commissioned Torakazu to translate the Avatamska Sutra (known in Japan as the 'Kegon-kyo Sutra') into German; the arduous task took him ten years to complete.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 土井哲学のスタ－トは「論理学」である。
sen.e: Doi's philosophy began with the "logics."
Doi's philosophy began with "logics."
Doi's philosophical stance began with Formal Logic.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、その根源に一貫して横たわるキ－ワ－ドは「悲劇性への意志」、ゲ－テの「敬虔性」、華厳の事事無礙としての「空の哲学」が予測できる。
sen.e: It can be expected that his fundamental idea lies in "Will to tragedy," Goethe's "Piety," and "Philosophy of Emptiness" as jijimuge of the Kegon school: "the mode of existence in which all phenomenal things are mutually unhindered and interfused."
sen.cmt: 事事無礙の英訳は以下から引用。http://shinku.nichibun.ac.jp/jpub/pdf/jr/JN2003.pdf
sen.e: It can be expected that his fundamental idea lies in "Will to tragedy," Goethe's "Piety," and "Philosophy of Emptiness" as jijimuge of the Kegon school: "the mode of existence in which all phenomenal things are mutually unhindered and interfused."

Nonetheless, it will come as no surprise to discover that the basic undercurrent running throughout all of his work is the idea of a "philosophy of emptiness" as expressed in his "Higekisei e no ishi" (The Will towards Tragedy), Goethe's "Piety," and the Kegon notion of "jiji muge" (the idea that everything in existence is interconnected and unobstructed).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 三高時代から晩年の獨協大学まで、その授業風景は学生達の魂を揺り動かし巻き込む独自の風貌と世界があったといわれる。
sen.e: Throughout his classes, from the day of Sanko to his last day of the Dokkyo University, it is said that he stirred the students' souls to make them involved, with his unique presence and character.

Throughout his classes, from the first day at Sanko to his last day at Dokkyo University, it is said that, through his unique presence and character, he stirred the students' souls and encouraged their involvement.

From his first day at the Third High School through to the very end of his career at Dokkyo University, Doi's teaching style, through his unique presence and worldview, is said to have truly inspired his students and drew them in.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: またその奇人・奇行ぶりは、三高での教え子だった青山光二の、『われらが風狂の師』に、土岐数馬として、しかし、家族の名前以外の固有名はそのままに描かれている。
sen.e: His character and eccentric behaviors were described in "Warera ga fukyo no shi" (Our eccentric teacher) by Koji AOYAMA, who was taught by Torakazu in Sanko: Torakazu was described as a person named "Kazuma TOKI" but all other proper names were used as they were except for the names of his family members.

His character and eccentric behavior were described in "Warera ga fukyo no shi (Our Eccentric Teacher)," by Koji AOYAMA, who was one of Torakazu's students at Sanko: Torakazu was described as a person called "Kazuma TOKI," but all other proper names were used as they were except for the names of his family members.

His unconventional character an eccentricities were described in "Warera ga fukyo no shi" (Our Wacky Teacher), by Koji AOYAMA, one of Doi's former students at the Third High School; in it, Doi was described under the pseudonym "Kazuma TOKI," but all other proper names used, except for the names of his family members, were real names.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: のちに武田泰淳の妻となる鈴木百合子(武田百合子)も登場する。
sen.e: Taijun TAKEDA, who later married Yuriko SUZUKI (Yuriko TAKEDA), also appeared in the book.
Taijun TAKEDA, who later married Yuriko SUZUKI (Yuriko TAKEDA), also appeared in the book.
Yuriko SUZUKI (who later married Taijun TAKEDA to become Yuriko TAKEDA) also appears as a character in Aoyama's book.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 三高では、田宮虎彦・野間宏・竹之内静雄・粟津則雄らも土井の教え子だった。
sen.e: In Sanko, Torahiko TAMIYA, Hiroshi NOMA, Shizuo TAKENOUCHI, and Norio AWAZU were also taught by Doi.
In Sanko, Torahiko TAMIYA, Hiroshi NOMA, Shizuo TAKENOUCHI and Norio AWAZU were also taught by Doi.
Torahiko TAMIYA, Hiroshi NOMA, Shizuo TAKENOUCHI and Norio AWAZU were also among Doi's students at the Third High School.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1950年、『ツァラトゥストラはこう語った』の翻訳を、『展望』誌上で「青木智夫」の名でこき下ろしたのは、ドイツ文学者・東大教授の手塚富雄である。
sen.e: In 1950, his translation of "Also sprach Zarathustra" was shot down on the magazine "Tenbo"(foresight) by Tomio TEZUKA, who was a scholar of German literature and a professor at the University of Tokyo, in the name of 'Tomoo AOKI.'

In 1950, his translation of "Also sprach Zarathustra" was shot down in the magazine "Tenbo (Foresight)" by Tomio TEZUKA, who was a scholar of German literature and a professor at the University of Tokyo, writing under the pen name 'Tomoo AOKI.'

In 1950, Doi's translation of "Also sprach Zarathustra" was lambasted in the magazine "Tenbo" (Foresight) by Tomio TEZUKA, a scholar of German literature and a professor at the University of Tokyo, writing under the pen name 'Tomoo AOKI.'
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また武田泰淳の、『ひかりごけ』の「異形の者」に出てくる哲学者は土井をモデルとしている。
sen.e: Taijun TAKEDA described a philosopher modeled on Doi in his piece 'Ikei no mono' in "Hikarigoke"(luminous moss).
Taijun TAKEDA described a philosopher modeled on Doi in his piece entitled 'Ikei no mono,' in "Hikarigoke (Luminous Moss)."
The philosopher Taijun TAKEDA describes in his "Ikei no mono," which was published in the magazine "Hikarigoke," was modeled after Doi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 結婚して虎賀壽は土井姓になったが、妻の土井杉野は、元東北大に学んだ学徒で、土井すぎのの名でアンナ・シュウエル『黒馬物語』の翻訳がある。
sen.e: Torakazu changed his family name to Doi upon marriage: his wife was Sugino DOI(土井杉野), who was a student at Tohoku University and translated "Black Beauty: The Autobiography of a Horse" written by Anna Sewell in the name of Sugino DOI(土井すぎの).

Torakazu changed his family name to Doi upon marriage: his wife was Sugino DOI (土井杉野), who was a student at Tohoku University and translated Anna Sewell's "Black Beauty: The Autobiography of a Horse" in the name of Sugino DOI (土井すぎの).

Torakazu did not actually change his surname to Doi until his marriage to Sugino DOI, a student at Tohoku University who translated Anna SEWELL's "Black Beauty: the Autobiography of a Horse" under a phoneticized version of her own name, Sugino DOI.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 土井杉野・長女土井佐保は晩年の土井の思索活動を最後まで支えた同志であった。
sen.e: Sugino DOI and the eldest daughter Saho DOI supported the last day of Doi for his philosophy until he died.
Sugino DOI and the eldest daughter, Saho DOI, supported Doi for the sake of his philosophy until he died.
Until Doi's death, his wife Sugino and their eldest daughter Saho DOI continued to support him in his philosophical pursuits.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
